awd_abstract_narration:
Although human infants readily develop some capacities for representing number and geometry, children's thinking extends far beyond these capacities when they learn school mathematics. The basic concepts and skills of arithmetic and geometry that children learn in elementary school are critical for all subsequent learning and practicing of mathematics and science, but their acquisition, in relation to younger children's preexisting numerical and geometrical concepts, is not well understood. The proposed experiments are guided by the hypothesis that children learn school mathematics by using symbols- both language and visual-spatial symbols such as pictures and maps- to combine productively the early-developing numerical and spatial representations that emerge in infancy. To test this hypothesis, the proposed experiments probe the relationship between children's performance on tests of core numerical and geometrical abilities and their performance on tests of symbolic arithmetic, map reading, and abstract geometrical reasoning. Some experiments use individual difference methods to test whether variability in children's sensitivity to core numerical or geometric information is associated with variability in the mastery of language or symbols or of more abstract mathematical concepts. Further experiments use training methods to investigate whether tasks that exercise children's core abilities or use of symbols enhance children's numerical or geometrical reasoning in tests of school mathematics. The training experiments probe both the existence of relationships between core and constructed mathematical abilities and the underlying cognitive and motivational processes that may account for these relationships. Through these investigations, the experiments aim both to contribute to basic understanding of mathematical cognition and to inform efforts to enhance children's mathematical learning and reasoning.

The proposed research has two complementary goals. First, it aims to shed light on the fundamental cognitive capacities that allow humans to develop knowledge of elementary school mathematics, especially the abstract concepts and rules of arithmetic and Euclidean geometry. Second, the research aims to develop better ways to aid children's learning of mathematics, by building on basic research findings concerning the nature and early development of reasoning in the core cognitive domains on which elementary school mathematics may be founded. To accomplish these goals, tasks that previously were developed as tools to probe the fundamental numerical and geometrical abilities of infants, children, and adults in diverse cultures are deployed both to assess patterns of variability in children's mathematical abilities and to serve as training interventions with the potential to enhance school math abilities. The experiments investigate not only the direct relations between early and later developing numerical and geometrical concepts, but also the ways in which children's developing mastery of symbols, cognitive control, and attitudes toward learning may modulate those relations and impact on children's learning and performance of school mathematics. Through these laboratory experiments, the research aims to achieve a better understanding of mature mathematical reasoning and to discover new ways to aid children's mastery of this critical domain of knowledge.

By investigating the sources of variability in children's mathematical reasoning and the experiences that enhance children's reasoning, the proposed research promises to contribute to efforts both to foster all children's learning of mathematics and to aid children who experience difficulty with learning in this domain. Because children's learning of mathematics is affected by motivational patterns as well as cognitive abilities, the experimental interventions aim to enhance not only the cognitive processes underlying mathematical reasoning but also children's attitudes towards mathematics, belief in the malleability of mathematical skills with practice, and sense of their own competence as mathematical learners. Because children often learn best in social contexts, the interventions aim to create a set of training materials that children can use to play with others, and experiments will compare these interventions to those instantiated in individualized interactive computer-training programs. The findings of this research should inform efforts to enhance children's learning of mathematics both in and outside of school, for 4- to 10-year-old children at all ability levels.

por.por_cntn:
Young children are extraordinary learners. With no explicit instruction, they learn to identify the people in their social world, master their languages and common motor skills, decipher the forms and functions of surrounding objects, discover the abstract concepts of mental states and physical causality that underlie our common sense understanding of people and things, and grapple with the intuitive concepts of number and geometry that serve as a gateway to learning of science and mathematics in school. Developmental cognitive science aims to achieve a deep understanding of children's learning by using powerful, laboratory-based tools, drawing on diverse disciplines in the biological, behavioral, and social sciences, to probe the nature and causes of children's emerging knowledge. With this understanding, it seeks to develop and evaluate ways to foster the learning of all children, especially those whose circumstances place them at risk of failing to leverage their inherent cognitive capacities to master the skills needed for success in the modern world. The present project focused on the development of the verbal and symbolic skills necessary for learning mathematics in primary school.

            Research in the first phase probed relationships between the intuitive knowledge of number and geometry that emerges in human infancy and guides learning throughout childhood, and children's mastery of new mathematical concepts, language, and symbols (see Spelke, What Babies Know, Oxford University Press, 2022). Children's intuitive and formal concepts were assessed within a single experimental session. Analyses revealed that the content and robustness of children's formal concepts of number and geometry, expressed by words, symbols, and operations of mental arithmetic or geometrical problem-solving, were systematically predicted by the intuitive concepts that children brought to bear in tasks assessing their sensitivity to small, exact numbers of objects; large, approximate numerical magnitudes; the shape properties of small-scale geometric forms; and the distances and directions connecting places in the navigable layout. In contrast, children's intuitive concepts of small, exact and large, approximate numbers had been found to be unrelated to each other, in past research (see Feigenson et al., Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 2004, and Spelke, Language Learning and Development, 2017, for reviews). In the present project, children's intuitive representations of the shapes of small-scale objects and the shape of the navigable layout were found to be unrelated as well (Dillon et al., 2013, 2015, 2016, 2017; Huang & Spelke, 2015). Thus, young children lack the unitary concepts of number and geometry at the foundations of formal mathematics.

            In light of these findings, experiments in this project next asked whether children used their developing knowledge of language and spatial symbols to form unitary representations of number and geometry. A series of experiments tested for, and found, relationships between children's intuitive mathematical representations, their learning of mathematical language and symbols, and their mastery of formal mathematical concepts (Huang & Spelke, 2015; Hyde et al., 2014; Khanum et al., 2016). Then we asked whether games that exercised only children's intuitive mathematical concepts enhanced their performance of school-taught mathematics. First, we tested whether number games-training experiments, exercising intuitive numerical concepts, yielded placebo effects on children's school math performance, finding that they did not (Dillon et al., 2015). Then we tested whether intuitive number and geometry games enhanced children's mastery of the language, symbols, and operations of formal mathematics. These studies provided evidence for enhancements to children's intuitive abilities but not their symbolic abilities, consistent with the findings from an independent and non-NSF funded project using the same activities in a large-scale randomized field experiment (Dillon et al., 2017). Finally, we asked whether games that exercised children's intuitive mathematical concepts, while pairing those concepts with the language and symbols of school mathematics, enhanced children's performance of school mathematics. As this project ended, emerging evidence from the present project suggested that they do (Spelke, 2021).

            More broadly, this research contributes to efforts to achieve a deeper understanding of how all children learn the fundamental concepts and skills that are critical for success in contemporary, technological societies. It also aims to foster children's learning, with special focus on children who are at risk of failing to develop the school-taught concepts and skills that are needed to flourish within their societies. Finally, this research aims to foster an integrated, interdisciplinary science of learning. This science, spanning fields from neurobiology and computational cognitive science to economics and education, aims to integrate research on the foundations of learning in multiple societies, at multiple time scales, with preregistered, randomized designs targeting the causal processes by which knowledge grows (Duflo & Spelke, Seminar, Paris School of Economics, 2018). It also seeks deeper insights into children's learning and education, by engaging developmental cognitive scientists with computer scientists around the effort to attain a deeper understanding of intelligence, human and artificial (e.g., Spelke, Seminar, Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, 2020).
